<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_destroy:
```c
void
MHD_pool_destroy (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  if (NULL == pool)
    return;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
  if (! pool->is_mmap)
    free (pool->memory);
  else
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && ! defined(_WIN32)
    munmap (pool->memory,
            pool->size);
#elif defined(_WIN32)
    VirtualFree (pool->memory,
                 0,
                 MEM_RELEASE);
#else
    abort ();
#endif
  free (pool);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
abort ();
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: abort() is a standard library function and does not call MHD_pool_destroy, so MHD_pool_destroy does not call itself. (Note: if the program installed a SIGABRT handler that itself called MHD_pool_destroy, a sequence MHD_pool_destroy -> abort() -> SIGABRT handler -> MHD_pool_destroy would create indirect recursion and thus violate Rule 17.2, but that is not caused by this code fragment itself.)
